name: Phosphorus
summary: Phosphorus is an essential mineral involved in bone health, cellular energy production, and neurotransmission, though supplementation is rarely needed outside of deficiency.
description: Phosphorus is the second most abundant mineral in the human body after calcium, with approximately 85% stored in bones and teeth as hydroxyapatite. It plays critical roles in energy metabolism (as ATP and phosphocreatine), cell signaling, acid-base balance, and neuronal function. Because phosphorus is widely available in the diet (meat, dairy, legumes, nuts, grains), deficiencies are uncommon except in cases of malnutrition, chronic alcoholism, or certain medical conditions. Supplementation may be considered in hypophosphatemia or specific clinical scenarios, but excessive intake can be harmful, particularly in kidney disease. Phosphorus supplements are generally used under medical supervision.

metadata.natural_source: Meat, fish, dairy, legumes, nuts, seeds, grains
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for psychiatric or general health indications)

primary_indications: Support of bone and mineral balance
off_label_uses: Potential adjunct in energy metabolism support (limited evidence)

items: Corrects electrolyte imbalances in refeeding syndrome

sections.text: Phosphorus, primarily in the form of phosphate, is essential for ATP and phosphocreatine energy systems, nucleic acid synthesis, and phospholipid-based membranes. It supports bone mineralization with calcium and regulates intracellular signaling pathways critical for cell and neuronal function.

adult.typical: 250–500 mg elemental phosphorus orally 1–2 times daily (for deficiency, individualized per labs)
adult.note: Dietary intake for adults: ~700 mg/day; supplementation usually unnecessary unless deficient.

sections.pediatric: Dosed based on weight and deficiency status under medical supervision.

sections.text: Correction of low phosphate levels may occur within days; long-term effects depend on underlying cause and continued monitoring.

other: Use caution in chronic kidney disease, as phosphorus retention can worsen outcomes.
Avoid over-the-counter use without monitoring serum phosphate.

items.risk: May bind phosphate and reduce absorption
May increase risk of hyperkalemia when combined with potassium phosphate salts

sections.pregnancy: Generally considered safe in normal dietary intake; supplementation only if deficient
sections.lactation: Safe in dietary amounts; supplementation requires supervision
sections.pediatrics: May be used under strict clinical supervision
sections.geriatrics: Monitor kidney function closely; risk of phosphate retention increases with age

sections.text: No tapering required; discontinue when deficiency resolves or if lab abnormalities develop.

items: Dietary phosphorus is abundant in Western diets; supplementation is rarely required.
Excess phosphorus is linked to cardiovascular disease risk, especially in CKD.
Phosphate salts (sodium, potassium, calcium phosphate) are the supplemental forms used.
